GUID Source.1: Indicate the source of the GUID that you have provided for your samples.

Unique ID.1: Field REQUIRED for ALL sample submission. Options: IGSN- http://www.geosamples.org/getigsn ; UUID- https://www.uuidgenerator.net/

Sample Name.1: ID that is present on the shipped sample. Human readable.

Analysis/Data Type.1: This field is constrained to contain only a set of limited terms that indicate the types of data that were generated. Include all the data types, this field can have multiple values separated by a ;

Number Technical Replicate.1: If sending multiple technical replicates of the same sample, indicate how many replicates are being sent

Replicate Number.1: If sending biological replicates, indicate the rep number here.

Source Material ID.1: A unique identifier assigned to an original material sample collected or to any derived sub-samples. The source material should be listed as a sample to inform details about parent material relationship.

sample linkage.1: A unique identifier to assign parent-child, subsample, or sibling samples. This is relevant when a sample or other material was used to generate the new sample. This field allows multiple entries separated by ; (Examples: Soil collected from the field will link with the soil used in an incubation. The soil a plant was grown in links to the plant sample. An original culture sample was transferred to a new vial and generated a new sample)

Growth Facility.1: Type of facility where the sample was collected or grown

Sample size.1: Total amount of sample sent to EMSL, include units

Collection Date.1: The date of sampling, either as an instance (single point) or interval.

Storage Condition.1: Detail how your sample was stored

Storage temperature.1: Details what temperature samples should be stored at

Geographical Location Name.1: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea name followed by specific region name. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html), or the GAZ ontology (http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/GAZ).
Geographical Location Name.2: country or sea name (INSDC or GAZ): region(GAZ), specific location name

latitude, longitude.1: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude and longitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system.

elevation-meters.1: Elevation of the sampling site is its height above a fixed reference point, most commonly the mean sea level. Elevation is mainly used when referring to points on the earth's surface, while altitude is used for points above the surface, such as an aircraft in flight or a spacecraft in orbit

Material Processing.1: A brief description of any processing applied to the sample during or after retrieving the sample from environment, or a link to the relevant protocol(s) performed.

sample collection method.1: The method employed for collecting the sample. This can be a citation or description

depth.1: The vertical distance below local surface. For sediment or soil samples depth is measured from sediment or soil surface, respectively. Depth can be reported as an interval for subsurface samples.

sample collection device.1: The device used to collect an environmental sample. Include dimensions of device if applicable

Sieve Size.1: Collection design of pooled samples and/or sieve size and amount of sample sieved

Filter Method.1: Type of filter used or how the sample was filteres

Plant Structure.1: Name of plant structure the sample was obtained from; for Plant Ontology (PO) (v releases/2017-12-14) terms, see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/PO, e.g. petiole epidermis (PO_0000051). If an individual flower is sampled, the sex of it can be recorded here.

Incubation Start Date.1: Date the incubation was started. Only relevant for incubation samples.

Incubation Collection Date.1: Date the incubation was harvested/collected/ended. Only relevant for incubation samples.

collection time.1: The time of sampling, either as an instance (single point) or interval. Time should be formatted as HH:MM:SS

common name.1: Common name of the host, e.g. Human

isolation and growth condition.1: Publication reference in the form of pubmed ID (pmid), digital object identifier (doi) or url for isolation and growth condition specifications of the organism/material

Growth Medium.1: Method of growth and medium/materials used

watering regimen/schedule treatment.1: Information about treatment involving an exposure to watering frequencies, treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include multiple regimens

air temperature regimen treatment.1: Information about treatment involving an exposure to varying temperatures; should include the temperature, treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include different temperature regimens

chemical administration.1: List of chemical compounds administered to the host or site where sampling occurred, and when (e.g. Antibiotics, n fertilizer, air filter); can include multiple compounds. For chemical entities of biological interest ontology (chebi) (v 163), http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/chebi

isotope exposure/addition treatment.1: List isotope exposure or addition applied to your sample.

gas evironment/exposure treatment.1: Use of conditions with differing gaseous environments; should include the name of gaseous compound, amount administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple gaseous environment regimens

climate environment treatment.1: Treatment involving an exposure to a particular climate; treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include multiple climates

humidity regimen/adition treatment.1: Information about treatment involving an exposure to varying degree of humidity; information about treatment involving use of growth hormones; should include amount of humidity administered, treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include multiple regimens

light regimen treatment.1: Information about treatment(s) involving exposure to light, including both light intensity and quality.

biotic regimen/addition treatment.1: Information about treatment(s) involving use of biotic factors, such as bacteria, viruses or fungi.

other treatments.1: If a treatment is applied to your samples and the provided "treatment" terms do not satisfy, please add it here. Multiple treatments can be entered here, separated by ;

Extraction method.1: If you, the user, performed an extraction, preparation, or processing before sending the sample to EMSL, what was it? This is only applicable when sending an "analytical sample". See README for more details on types of samples.

Method Test.1: If your samples are TEST sample ONLY, please provide information on what you're hoping this test will resolve.

altitude-meters.1: Altitude is a term used to identify heights of objects such as airplanes, space shuttles, rockets, atmospheric balloons and heights of places such as atmospheric layers and clouds. It is used to measure the height of an object which is above the earthbs surface. In this context, the altitude measurement is the vertical distance between the earth's surface above sea level and the sampled position in the air

Other.1: Other details about your sample that you feel can't be accurately represented in the available columns.

amount or size of sample collected.1: This referes to the TOTAL amount of sample collected from the experiment. NOT the amount sent to EMSL or collected for a specific analysis.

experimental factor.1: Experimental factors are essentially the variable aspects of an experiment design which can be used to describe an experiment, or set of experiments, in an increasingly detailed manner. This field accepts ontology terms from Experimental Factor Ontology (EFO) and/or Ontology for Biomedical Investigations (OBI). For a browser of EFO (v 2.95) terms, please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/EFO; for a browser of OBI (v 2018-02-12) terms please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/OBI

experimental factor- other.1: Other details about your sample that you feel can't be accurately represented in the available columns.

non microbial biomass.1: Amount of biomass; should include the name for the part of biomass measured, e.g.insect, plant, total. Can include multiple measurements separated by ;

non-microbial biomass method.1: Reference or method used in determining biomass

observed biotic relationship.1: Description of relationship(s) between the subject organism and other organism(s) it is associated with. E.g., parasite on species X; mutualist with species Y. The target organism is the subject of the relationship, and the other organism(s) is the object

encoded traits.1: Should include key traits like antibiotic resistance or xenobiotic degradation phenotypes for plasmids, converting genes for phage
encoded traits.2: for plasmid: antibiotic resistance {text}; for phage: converting genes {text}

host specificity or range.1: The NCBI taxonomy identifier of the specific host if it is known

known pathogenicity.1: To what is the entity pathogenic

propagation.1: This field is specific to different taxa. For phages: lytic/lysogenic, for plasmids: incompatibility group, for eukaryotes: sexual/asexual (Note: there is the strong opinion to name phage propagation obligately lytic or temperate, therefore we also give this choice

reference for biomaterial.1: Primary publication if isolated before genome publication; otherwise, primary genome report.

specific host.1: If there is a host involved, please provide its taxid (or environmental if not actually isolated from the dead or alive host - i.e. a pathogen could be isolated from a swipe of a bench etc) and report whether it is a laboratory or natural host)

subspecific genetic lineage.1: Information about the genetic distinctness of the sequenced organism below the subspecies level, e.g., serovar, serotype, biotype, ecotype, or any relevant genetic typing schemes like Group I plasmid. Subspecies should not be recorded in this term, but in the NCBI taxonomy. Supply both the lineage name and the lineage rank separated by a colon, e.g., biovar:abc123.

trophic level.1: Trophic levels are the feeding position in a food chain. Microbes can be a range of producers (e.g. chemolithotroph)

ancestral data.1: Information about either pedigree or other ancestral information description

antibiotic regimen.1: Information about treatment involving antibiotic administration; should include the name of antibiotic, amount administered, treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include multiple antibiotic regimens
antibiotic regimen.2: antibiotic name {text} ;antibiotic amount {float} {unit} ;treatment interval and duration {Rn/start_time/end_time/duration}

chemical mutagen.1: Treatment involving use of mutagens; should include the name of mutagen, amount administered, treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include multiple mutagen regimens
chemical mutagen.2: mutagen name {text};mutagen amount {float} {unit};treatment interval and duration {Rn/start_time/end_time/duration}

culture rooting medium.1: Name or reference for the hydroponic or in vitro culture rooting medium; can be the name of a commonly used medium or reference to a specific medium, e.g. Murashige and Skoog medium. If the medium has not been formally published, use the rooting medium descriptors.

fertilizer regimen.1: Information about treatment involving the use of fertilizers; should include the name of fertilizer, amount administered, treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include multiple fertilizer regimens
fertilizer regimen.2: fertilizer name{text}; fertilizer amount {float} {unit}; treatment interval and duration {Rn/start_time/end_time/duration}

fungicide regimen.1: Information about treatment involving use of fungicides; should include the name of fungicide, amount administered, treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include multiple fungicide regimens
fungicide regimen.2: fungicide name {text}; fungicide amount {float} {unit}; treatment interval and duration {Rn/start_time/end_time/duration}

genetic modification.1: Genetic modifications of the genome of an organism, which may occur naturally by spontaneous mutation, or be introduced by some experimental means, e.g. specification of a transgene or the gene knocked-out or details of transient transfection

gravity.1: Information about treatment involving use of gravity factor to study various types of responses in presence, absence or modified levels of gravity; treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include multiple treatments
gravity.2: gravity factor value {float} {unit};treatment interval and duration {Rn/start_time/end_time/duration}

growth habit.1: Characteristic shape, appearance or growth form of a plant species

growth hormone regimen.1: Information about treatment involving use of growth hormones; should include the name of growth hormone, amount administered, treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include multiple growth hormone regimens
growth hormone regimen.2: growth hormone name {text}; growth hormone amount {text} {unit}; treatment interval and duration {Rn/start_time/end_time/duration}

herbicide regimen.1: Information about treatment involving use of herbicides; information about treatment involving use of growth hormones; should include the name of herbicide, amount administered, treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include multiple regimens
herbicide regimen.2: herbicide name {text}; herbicide amount {value} {unit}; treatment interval and duration {Rn/start_time/end_time/duration}

host age.1: Age of host at the time of sampling; relevant scale depends on species and study, e.g. Could be seconds for amoebae or centuries for trees

host disease status.1: List of diseases with which the host has been diagnosed; can include multiple diagnoses. The value of the field depends on host; for humans the terms should be chosen from the DO (Human Disease Ontology) at https://www.disease-ontology.org, non-human host diseases are free text
host disease status.2: disease name or Disease Ontology term {text}|{termLabel} {[termID]}

host infra-specific name.1: Taxonomic information about the host below subspecies level

host infra-specific rank.1: Taxonomic rank information about the host below subspecies level, such as variety, form, rank etc.

host life stage.1: Description of life stage of host

host phenotype.1: Phenotype of human or other host. For phenotypic quality ontology (pato) (v 2018-03-27) terms, please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/pato. For Human Phenotype Ontology (HP) (v 2018-06-13) please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/HP

observed host symbionts.1: The taxonomic name of the organism(s) found living in mutualistic, commensalistic, or parasitic symbiosis with the specific host.

host total mass.1: Total mass of the host at collection, the unit depends on host

mechanical damage.1: Information about any mechanical damage exerted on the plant; can include multiple damages and sites

mineral nutrient regimen.1: Information about treatment involving the use of mineral supplements; should include the name of mineral nutrient, amount administered, treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include multiple mineral nutrient regimens
mineral nutrient regimen.2: mineral nutrient name {text}; mineral nutrient amount {value} {unit}; treatment interval and duration {Rn/start_time/end_time/duration}

non-mineral nutrient regimen.1: Information about treatment involving the exposure of plant to non-mineral nutrient such as oxygen, hydrogen or carbon; should include the name of non-mineral nutrient, amount administered, treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include multiple non-mineral nutrient regimens
non-mineral nutrient regimen.2: non-mineral nutrient name {text}; non-mineral nutrient amount {value} {unit}; treatment interval and duration {Rn/start_time/end_time/duration}

pesticide regimen.1: Information about treatment involving use of insecticides; should include the name of pesticide, amount administered, treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include multiple pesticide regimens
pesticide regimen.2: pesticide name {text}; pesticide amount {value} {unit}; treatment interval and duration {Rn/start_time/end_time/duration}

pH regimen.1: Information about treatment involving exposure of plants to varying levels of ph of the growth media, treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include multiple regimen

plant growth medium.1: Specification of the media for growing the plants or tissue cultured samples, e.g. soil, aeroponic, hydroponic, in vitro solid culture medium, in vitro liquid culture medium. Recommended value is a specific value from EO:plant growth medium (follow this link for terms http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/EO_0007147) or other controlled vocabulary
plant growth medium.2: {termLabel} {[termID]} or [husk|other artificial liquid medium|other artificial solid medium|peat moss|perlite|pumice|sand|soil|vermiculite|water]

plant product.1: Substance produced by the plant, where the sample was obtained from

plant sex.1: Sex of the reproductive parts on the whole plant, e.g. pistillate, staminate, monoecieous, hermaphrodite.

radiation regimen.1: Information about treatment involving exposure of plant or a plant part to a particular radiation regimen; should include the radiation type, amount or intensity administered, treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include multiple radiation regimens
radiation regimen.2: radiation type name {text}; radiation amount {value} {unit}; treatment interval and duration {Rn/start_time/end_time/duration}

rainfall regimen.1: Information about treatment involving an exposure to a given amount of rainfall, treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include multiple regimens
rainfall regimen.2: measurement value {value} {unit}; treatment interval and duration {Rn/start_time/end_time/duration}

rooting conditions.1: Relevant rooting conditions such as field plot size, sowing density, container dimensions, number of plants per container.

rooting medium carbon.1: Source of organic carbon in the culture rooting medium; e.g. sucrose.

rooting medium macronutrients.1: Measurement of the culture rooting medium macronutrients (N,P, K, Ca, Mg, S); e.g. KH2PO4 (170¬¨‚Ä†mg/L).

rooting medium micronutrients.1: Measurement of the culture rooting medium micronutrients (Fe, Mn, Zn, B, Cu, Mo); e.g. H3BO3 (6.2¬¨‚Ä†mg/L).

rooting medium pH.1: pH measurement of the culture rooting medium; e.g. 5.5.

rooting medium regulators.1: Growth regulators in the culture rooting medium such as cytokinins, auxins, gybberellins, abscisic acid; e.g. 0.5¬¨‚Ä†mg/L NAA.

rooting medium solidifier.1: Specification of the solidifying agent in the culture rooting medium; e.g. agar.

rooting medium organic supplements.1: Organic supplements of the culture rooting medium, such as vitamins, amino acids, organic acids, antibiotics activated charcoal; e.g. nicotinic acid (0.5¬¨‚Ä†mg/L).

salt regimen.1: Information about treatment involving use of salts as supplement to liquid and soil growth media; should include the name of salt, amount administered, treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include multiple salt regimens
salt regimen.2: salt name {text}; salt amount {value} {unit}; treatment interval and duration {Rn/start_time/end_time/duration}

sample disease stage.1: Stage of the disease at the time of sample collection, e.g. inoculation, penetration, infection, growth and reproduction, dissemination of pathogen.

seasonal environment.1: Treatment involving an exposure to a particular season (e.g. Winter, summer, rabi, rainy etc.), treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment
seasonal environment.2: seasonal environment name {text}; treatment interval and duration {Rn/start_time/end_time/duration}

standing water regimen.1: Treatment involving an exposure to standing water during a plant's life span, types can be flood water or standing water, treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include multiple regimens
standing water regimen.2: standing water type {text}; treatment interval and duration {Rn/start_time/end_time/duration}

tissue culture growth media.1: Description of plant tissue culture growth media used

water temperature regimen.1: Information about treatment involving an exposure to water with varying degree of temperature, treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include multiple regimens
water temperature regimen.2: measurement value {value} {unit}; treatment interval and duration {Rn/start_time/end_time/duration}

miscellaneous parameter.1: Any other measurement performed or parameter collected, that is not listed here

organism count.1: Total cell count of any organism (or group of organisms) per gram, volume or area of sample, should include name of organism followed by count. The method that was used for the enumeration (e.g. qPCR, atp, mpn, etc.) Should also be provided. (example: total prokaryotes; 3.5e7 cells per ml; qpcr)

perturbation.1: Type of perturbation, e.g. chemical administration, physical disturbance, etc., coupled with perturbation regimen including how many times the perturbation was repeated, how long each perturbation lasted, and the start and end time of the entire perturbation period; can include multiple perturbation types
perturbation.2: perturbation type name {text}; perturbation interval and duration {Rn/start_time/end_time/duration}

temperature.1: Temperature of the sample at the time of sampling

pH.1: pH measurement of the sample, or liquid portion of sample, or aqueous phase of the fluid

pH method.1: Reference or method used in determining ph

ammonium.1: Concentration of ammonium in the sample

calcium.1: Concentration of calcium in the sample

carbon/nitrogen ratio.1: Ratio of amount or concentrations of carbon to nitrogen

chloride.1: Concentration of chloride in the sample

density.1: Density of the sample, which is its mass per unit volume (aka volumetric mass density)

diether lipids.1: Concentration of diether lipids; can include multiple types of diether lipids

dissolved carbon dioxide.1: Concentration of dissolved carbon dioxide in the sample or liquid portion of the sample

dissolved inorganic carbon.1: Dissolved inorganic carbon concentration in the sample, typically measured after filtering the sample using a 0.45 micrometer filter

dissolved organic carbon.1: Concentration of dissolved organic carbon in the sample, liquid portion of the sample, or aqueous phase of the fluid

dissolved organic nitrogen.1: Dissolved organic nitrogen concentration measured as; total dissolved nitrogen - NH4 - NO3 - NO2

magnesium.1: Concentration of magnesium in the sample

mean peak friction velocity.1: Measurement of mean peak friction velocity

n-alkanes.1: Concentration of n-alkanes; can include multiple n-alkanes

nitrite.1: Concentration of nitrite in the sample

phaeopigments.1: Concentration of phaeopigments; can include multiple phaeopigments

phospholipid fatty acid.1: Concentration of phospholipid fatty acids; can include multiple values
phospholipid fatty acid.2: phospholipid fatty acid name {text}; measurement value {float} {unit}

potassium.1: Concentration of potassium in the sample

pressure.1: Pressure to which the sample is subject to, in atmospheres

redox potential.1: Redox potential, measured relative to a hydrogen cell, indicating oxidation or reduction potential

sulfate.1: Concentration of sulfate in the sample

sulfide.1: Concentration of sulfide in the sample

total depth of water column.1: Measurement of total depth of water column

turbidity.1: Measure of the amount of cloudiness or haziness in water caused by individual particles

salinity.1: Salinity is the total concentration of all dissolved salts in a water sample. While salinity can be measured by a complete chemical analysis, this method is difficult and time consuming. More often, it is instead derived from the conductivity measurement. This is known as practical salinity. These derivations compare the specific conductance of the sample to a salinity standard such as seawater

salinity method.1: Method used to determine sample salinity

alkalinity.1: Alkalinity, the ability of a solution to neutralize acids to the equivalence point of carbonate or bicarbonate

nitrate.1: Concentration of nitrate in the sample

atmospheric data.1: Measurement of atmospheric data; can include multiple data

bacterial production.1: Bacterial production in the water column measured by isotope uptake

bacterial respiration.1: Measurement of bacterial respiration in the water column

downward PAR.1: Visible waveband radiance and irradiance measurements in the water column

fluorescence.1: Raw or converted fluorescence of water

primary production.1: Measurement of primary production, generally measured as isotope uptake

total dissolved nitrogen.1: Total dissolved nitrogen concentration, reported as nitrogen, measured by: total dissolved nitrogen = NH4 + NO3NO2 + dissolved organic nitrogen

total nitrogen concentration.1: Total nitrogen concentration of water samples, calculated by: total nitrogen = total dissolved nitrogen + particulate nitrogen. Can also be measured without filtering, reported as nitrogen

total phosphorus.1: Total phosphorus concentration in the sample, calculated by: total phosphorus = total dissolved phosphorus + particulate phosphorus

water current.1: Measurement of magnitude and direction of flow within a fluid

size-fraction lower threshold.1: Refers to the mesh/pore size used to pre-filter/pre-sort the sample. Materials larger than the size threshold are excluded from the sample

size-fraction upper threshold.1: Refers to the mesh/pore size used to retain the sample. Materials smaller than the size threshold are excluded from the sample

methane.1: Methane (gas) amount or concentration at the time of sampling

particle classification.1: Particles are classified, based on their size, into six general categories:clay, silt, sand, gravel, cobbles, and boulders; should include amount of particle preceded by the name of the particle type; can include multiple values

porosity.1: Porosity of deposited sediment is volume of voids divided by the total volume of sample

sediment type.1: Information about the sediment type based on major constituents

water content method.1: Reference or method used in determining the water content of soil

microbial biomass.1: The part of the organic matter in the soil that constitutes living microorganisms smaller than 5-10 micrometer. If you keep this, you would need to have correction factors used for conversion to the final units

microbial biomass method.1: Reference or method used in determining microbial biomass

microbial biomass carbon.1: The part of the organic matter in the soil that constitutes living microorganisms smaller than 5-10 micrometer. If you keep this, you would need to have correction factors used for conversion to the final units

microbial biomass carbon method.1: Reference or method used in determining microbial biomass

microbial biomass nitrogen.1: The part of the organic matter in the soil that constitutes living microorganisms smaller than 5-10 micrometer. If you keep this, you would need to have correction factors used for conversion to the final units

microbial biomass nitrogen method.1: Reference or method used in determining microbial biomass nitrogen

organic nitrogen method.1: Method used for obtaining organic nitrogen

history/extreme events.1: Unusual physical events that may have affected microbial populations

history/fire.1: Historical and/or physical evidence of fire

history/flooding.1: Historical and/or physical evidence of flooding

total nitrogen content.1: Total nitrogen content of the sample

total nitrogen content method.1: Reference or method used in determining the total nitrogen

total organic carbon method.1: Reference or method used in determining total organic carbon

total organic carbon.1: Definition for soil: total organic carbon content of the soil, definition otherwise: total organic carbon content

history/agrochemical additions.1: Addition of fertilizers, pesticides, etc. - amount and time of applications

extreme_unusual_properties/Al saturation.1: Reference or method used in determining Al saturation

mean annual precipitation.1: The average of all annual precipitation values known, or an estimated equivalent value derived by such methods as regional indexes or Isohyetal maps.

history/crop rotation.1: Whether or not crop is rotated, and if yes, rotation schedule

current vegetation.1: Vegetation classification from one or more standard classification systems, or agricultural crop

current vegetation method.1: Reference or method used in vegetation classification

drainage classification.1: Drainage classification from a standard system such as the USDA system

soil_taxonomic/FAO classification.1: Soil classification from the FAO World Reference Database for Soil Resources. The list can be found at http://www.fao.org/nr/land/sols/soil/wrb-soil-maps/reference-groups

extreme_unusual_properties/heavy metals.1: Heavy metals present and concentrationsany drug used by subject and the frequency of usage; can include multiple heavy metals and concentrations
Reference or method used in determining heavy metals

horizon.1: Specific layer in the land area which measures parallel to the soil surface and possesses physical characteristics which differ from the layers above and beneath

horizon method.1: Reference or method used in determining the horizon

links to additional analysis.1: Link to additional analysis results performed on the sample

link to classification information.1: Link to digitized soil maps or other soil classification information

soil_taxonomic/local classification.1: Soil classification based on local soil classification system

soil_taxonomic/local classification meth.1: Reference or method used in determining the local soil classification

history/previous land use method.1: Reference or method used in determining previous land use and dates

profile position.1: Cross-sectional position in the hillslope where sample was collected.sample area position in relation to surrounding areas

mean seasonal precipitation.1: The average of all seasonal precipitation values known, or an estimated equivalent value derived by such methods as regional indexes or Isohyetal maps.

slope aspect.1: The direction a slope faces. While looking down a slope use a compass to record the direction you are facing (direction or degrees); e.g., nw or 315 degrees. This measure provides an indication of sun and wind exposure that will influence soil temperature and evapotranspiration.

slope gradient.1: Commonly called 'slope'. The angle between ground surface and a horizontal line (in percent). This is the direction that overland water would flow. This measure is usually taken with a hand level meter or clinometer

soil type.1: Soil series name or other lower-level classification

soil type method.1: Reference or method used in determining soil series name or other lower-level classification

texture.1: The relative proportion of different grain sizes of mineral particles in a soil, as described using a standard system; express as % sand (50 um to 2 mm), silt (2 um to 50 um), and clay (<2 um) with textural name (e.g., silty clay loam) optional.

texture method.1: Reference or method used in determining soil texture

biochemical oxygen demand.1: a measure of the relative oxygen-depletion effect of a waste contaminant

chemical oxygen demand.1: a measure of the relative oxygen-depletion effect of a waste contaminant

efficiency percent.1: percentage of volatile solids removed from the anaerobic digestor

emulsions.1: amount or concentration of substances such as paints, adhesives, mayonnaise, hair colorants, emulsified oils, etc.; can include multiple emulsion types

gaseous substances.1: amount or concentration of substances such as hydrogen sulfide, carbon dioxide, methane, etc.; can include multiple substances

industrial effluent percent.1: percentage of industrial effluents received by wastewater treatment plant

inorganic particles.1: concentration of particles such as sand, grit, metal particles, ceramics, etc.; can include multiple particles

organic particles.1: concentration of particles such as faeces, hairs, food, vomit, paper fibers, plant material, humus, etc.

pre-treatment.1: the process of pre-treatment removes materials that can be easily collected from the raw wastewater

primary treatment.1: the process to produce both a generally homogeneous liquid capable of being treated biologically and a sludge that can be separately treated or processed

reactor type.1: anaerobic digesters can be designed and engineered to operate using a number of different process configurations, as batch or continuous, mesophilic, high solid or low solid, and single stage or multistage

secondary treatment.1: the process for substantially degrading the biological content of the sewage

sewage type.1: type of wastewater treatment plant as municipial or industrial

sludge retention time.1: the time activated sludge remains in reactor

soluble inorganic material.1: concentration of substances such as ammonia, road-salt, sea-salt, cyanide, hydrogen sulfide, thiocyanates, thiosulfates, etc.
soluble inorganic material.2: soluble inorganic material name {text}; measurement value {float} {unit}

soluble organic material.1: concentration of substances such as urea, fruit sugars, soluble proteins, drugs, pharmaceuticals, etc.
soluble organic material.2: soluble organic material name {text}; measurement value {float} {unit}

suspended solids.1: concentration of substances including a wide variety of material, such as silt, decaying plant and animal matter, etc,; can include multiple substances

tertiary treatment.1: the process providing a final treatment stage to raise the effluent quality before it is discharged to the receiving environment

total phosphate.1: total amount or concentration of phosphate

wastewater type.1: the origin of wastewater such as human waste, rainfall, storm drains, etc.
